history.content:
Maybe you enjoy the theory side of CS more then? I thought the same after 61B, but have enjoyed 170, 188, 189, 127, etc etc quite a lot. A lot of upperdivs are less about big projects and more implementing concepts from the course: for example, 186 has a lot of coding, but it is fairly structured, so I never felt frustrated with not knowing what to do.

Basically, definitely keep going before deciding not to do CS.

------------

Different perspective here - wasn't the biggest fan of 61B's content, but fell in love with 61C and am focusing on computer hardware and systems programming! There are a lot of avenues you can take.

Maybe you enjoy the theory side of CS more then? I thought the same after 61B, but have enjoyed 170, 188, 189, 127, etc etc quite a lot. A lot of upperdivs are less about big projects and more implementing concepts from the course: for example, 186 has a lot of coding, but it is fairly structured, so I never felt frustrated with not knowing what to do.

Basically, definitely keep going before deciding not to do CS.

------------

children.subject: If you're into probability and ML...data science!

I don’t know the answer to this, but I just wanted to recommend that you visit some of the Theory professors in their office hours and chat with them. I’m sure they’d be happy to discuss possible career paths!
Thanks!! I'm actually taking 70 now, and loves it by far. What are the possible career paths if I want to go on a more theoretical track?

I didn't like 61B very much.

Flip side, I loved 70/126/170

Computer Science is a big field, explore all aspects! I am sure you will find something you enjoy.

history.content:
The reality is that the EECS department is a very big tent that has room for lots of diverse intellectual interests. It is completely normal for students to find some things more or less appealing to them, and that is fine. Once a student has mastered the lower division six courses, there are many different directions that you can go. And it isn't even whole classes, many of the lower-division courses have lots of different experiences inside them. (Perhaps the most unitary in spirit is 70, and even that has parts that appeal to different personalities.) You should ask yourself what parts you enjoyed and then see how to build a core sequence of upper-division courses in that direction, while making sure you get some diversity exposure beyond the lower divs even to parts you liked less.

So, for a student who likes 70 and say the more inferential dimensions of EE16AB, the logical next upper-divs are 170, 126, and 127. They're all different, but are fundamentally more "mathy" in their perspective. 170 will be most fun for students who liked 70 and 61B. 126 will be most fun for students who liked 70's probability parts. 127 will be most fun for students who liked the rigor of 70, and the linear-algebraic inference and problem reductions in EE16AB. Students who really liked the DFT components of 16B, and the symbol manipulation dimensions of some of 70 will enjoy 120. From these, students can build forward to even more advanced courses.

children.subject: Anything in the 16X section will be great. Popular courses from that section include 161, 162, and 168. Also, even though its theory, take 170.
for me it's the opposite, i strongly dislike cs70 due to personal interests but love cs61b. any advice on what classes to take in the future?

history.content:
Hi all,

The question is as the topic: If I don't enjoy 61B and its projects at all, does it mean computer science is not really for me? Love to hear your experiences!
history.subject: If I don't enjoy 61B and its projects at all, does it mean computer science is not really for me?
